title-group.article-title: Functional connectome automatically differentiates multiple system atrophy (parkinsonian type) from idiopathic Parkinson's disease at early stages

aff.institution: The First Hospital of China Medical University
The First Hospital of China Medical University

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Differentiating the parkinsonian variant of multiple system atrophy (MSA‐P) from idiopathic Parkinson's disease (IPD) is challenging, especially in the early stages. This study aimed to investigate differences and similarities in the brain functional connectomes of IPD and MSA‐P patients and use machine learning methods to explore the diagnostic utility of these features. Resting‐state fMRI data were acquired from 88 healthy controls, 76 MSA‐P patients, and 53 IPD patients using a 3.0 T scanner. The whole‐brain functional connectome was constructed by thresholding the Pearson correlation matrices of 116 regions, and topological properties were evaluated through graph theory approaches. Connectome measurements were used as features in machine learning models (random forest [RF]/logistic regression [LR]/support vector machine) to distinguish IPD and MSA‐P patients. Regarding graph metrics, early IPD and MSA‐P patients shared network topological properties. Both patient groups showed functional connectivity disruptions within the cerebellum‐basal ganglia‐cortical network, but these disconnections were mainly in the cortico‐thalamo‐cerebellar circuits in MSA‐P patients and the basal ganglia‐thalamo‐cortical circuits in IPD patients. Among the connectome parameters, t tests combined with the RF method identified 15 features, from which the LR classifier achieved the best diagnostic performance on the validation set (accuracy = 92.31%, sensitivity = 90.91%, specificity = 93.33%, area under the receiver operating characteristic curve = 0.89). MSA‐P and IPD patients show similar whole‐brain network topological alterations. MSA‐P primarily affects cerebellar nodes, and IPD primarily affects basal ganglia nodes; both conditions disrupt the cerebellum‐basal ganglia‐cortical network. Moreover, functional connectome parameters showed outstanding value in the differential diagnosis of early MSA‐P and IPD.

We investigated brain functional connectome abnormalities in patients with idiopathic Parkinson's disease (IPD) and parkinsonian variant of multiple system atrophy (MSA‐P) using resting‐state functional magnetic resonance imaging, demonstrating that “disconnection” within the cortico‐basal ganglia‐cerebellar network serve as the cornerstone of a differential diagnosis. IPD patients have decreased functional connectivity (FC) in the basal ganglia‐cortical circuit, whereas early‐stage MSA‐P patients have reduced FC in the cerebellum‐cortical circuit.

institution-wrap.institution: National Natural Science Foundation of China

p.mixed-citation: Chen, B. , Cui, W. , Wang, S. , Sun, A. , Yu, H. , Liu, Y. , He, J. , & Fan, G. (2023). Functional connectome automatically differentiates multiple system atrophy (parkinsonian type) from idiopathic Parkinson's disease at early stages. Human Brain Mapping, 44(6), 2176–2190. 10.1002/hbm.26201 36661217

def.p: part III of Movement Disorder Society‐Sponsored Revision of the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale
parkinsonian variant of multiple system atrophy

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Idiopathic Parkinson's disease (IPD) and multiple system atrophy (MSA) are common progressive neurodegenerative diseases in the ageing population (Palma et al., 2018). MSA with predominant parkinsonism (MSA‐P) is one of several parkinsonian syndromes and has many overlapping symptoms with IPD (Palma et al., 2018). Although the pathological alterations of the two diseases differ (Song et al., 2007; Tong et al., 2010; Valdinocci et al., 2018), approximately 20% of MSA‐P cases are misdiagnosed as IPD in the early stages (Kim et al., 2015).

Because the treatment options and prognosis for these two diseases are very different, a timely and precise diagnosis is critical for optimal patient management. Additionally, it remains unclear which pathophysiological mechanisms are shared between these two disorders and which are distinct. This is an unfavorable situation for comprehending MSA‐P patients' more rapid progression and temporary dopaminergic responsiveness, as well as developing effective therapies that address the cause (Fanciulli et al., 2019). Over the last decade, many studies have attempted to detect the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying IPD and MSA/MSA‐P through magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approaches, such as resting‐state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rs‐fMRI) (N. Wang et al., 2019), diffusion MRI (B. Chen et al., 2017), and voxel‐based morphometry (Erro et al., 2020).

In recent years, rs‐fMRI‐based brain connectome analyses, including the assessment of functional connectivity (FC) (Hohenfeld et al., 2018) and graph theory topological metrics, have been increasingly employed in neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer's disease (D. Wang et al., 2020), subjective cognitive decline (Xu et al., 2020), and IPD (Chung et al., 2020; De Micco et al., 2021; Hassan et al., 2017; Huang et al., 2019; Lopes et al., 2017; Suo et al., 2017), providing a new perspective to understand the pathological mechanism of these diseases. In IPD patients, connectome analyses can identify dysfunctional patterns related to cognitive (Hassan et al., 2017) and motor (Chung et al., 2020) symptoms and may also provide neuroimaging markers useful for making an early diagnosis (Huang et al., 2019), assessing disease severity (Suo et al., 2017), predicting outcomes and monitoring treatment responses to deep brain stimulation (Shang et al., 2020). Regarding global graph theory attributes, a series of studies found a lower clustering coefficient (Cp) and local efficiency (Eloca) in IPD patients than in healthy controls (HCs) (Prajapati & Emerson, 2021; Suo et al., 2017), indicating that the topological organization is disrupted and that the brain functional network shifts towards randomization. Both nodal graph metrics and regional FC measures reflect the local properties of the functional network; previous studies (Prajapati & Emerson, 2021; Suo et al., 2017) have found abnormalities located in the default‐mode network (DMN), sensorimotor network (SMN), and temporal‐occipital regions. Some results have been inconsistent; Suo et al. found decreased FC strength in the SMN, DMN, and temporal‐occipital areas (Suo et al., 2017), while Prajapati et al. reported increased connections in the DMN and occipital regions (Prajapati & Emerson, 2021). Furthermore, Shang et al. discovered that whole‐brain FC states could predict the outcome of deep brain stimulation in IPD patients (Shang et al., 2020).

To the best of our knowledge, little is known about the (re)organization of the functional connectome in MSA‐P or MSA. Zheng et al. (2020) investigated the functional network topology of 24 MSA patients and 20 HCs and identified nodal attribute abnormalities mainly in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and cerebellum. However, Sako et al. (2019) recruited 23 IPD patients, 11 MSA patients, and 11 HCs and concluded that neither IPD nor MSA patients had significant alterations in global‐ or nodal‐level metrics. Recent research by N. Wang et al. (2019) and Baggio et al. (2019) found that MSA patients displayed lower FC strength between the cerebellar dentate nucleus (DN) and DMN regions than IPD patients or HCs. In contrast, Yao et al. (2017) found that IPD patients showed weaker functional coupling in the DN‐DMN circuitry than MSA‐P patients or HCs. In summary, evidence shows that IPD is associated with variable functional connectome changes that depend on disease stage, phenotype, and medication status, whereas the (relatively few) results from MSA‐P patients are still inconsistent. Furthermore, most of these studies involved small samples, and the results were based on group‐level comparisons; no attempt was made to distinguish IPD from MSA patients at the individual level.

Recently, studies have employed rs‐fMRI parameters as inputs to machine learning algorithms to evaluate the potential of neuroimaging for individual‐level diagnosis, and encouraging results have been obtained from individuals with cognitive impairment (Xu et al., 2020), Alzheimer's disease (Hojjati et al., 2017), and IPD (Cao et al., 2020). A study by Baggio et al. (2019) used cerebellar network measurements as features in a support vector machine (SVM) and achieved 78.33% accuracy in differentiating MSA from IPD. However, that study included only 30 MSA patients, and the patients were not in the early stages of the disease.

In the current study, we investigated the (re)organization of functional brain networks (i.e., the functional connectome) in early‐stage IPD and MSA‐P patients using graph theory metrics and FC in an attempt to provide novel data for explaining different pathophysiological mechanisms in IPD and MSA‐P. Finally, we used machine learning approaches to identify discriminative features from functional connectome measurements that can differentiate early‐stage MSA‐P patients from IPD patients at the individual level.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: All participants gave informed consent in accordance with local ethics committee norms. A total of 236 participants were recruited from The First Hospital of China Medical University. All subjects were right‐handed, and the patients were in early stages of the disease. Sixty‐four patients were diagnosed with IPD according to the clinical diagnostic criteria of the UK Brain Bank (Hughes et al., 1992), while 84 patients met the MSA‐P diagnostic criteria (second edition, 2008) (Gilman et al., 2008). Patients were excluded if they had (1) disease duration (onset of symptoms) >3 years; (2) Hoehn and Yahr (H‐Y) stage >2.5 (Bhidayasiri & Tarsy, 2012); or (3) a history of any other organic or neurological diseases. MR scans and clinical symptom assessments were conducted on patients in the “off” state (i.e., discontinued antiparkinsonian medications for at least 12 h). Furthermore, 88 age‐, gender‐, and education‐matched volunteers were defined as HCs.

sec.title: Clinical assessment
sec.p: Antiparkinsonian medication dosages were converted to levodopa equivalent daily dose (LEDD) using the algorithm of Tomlinson et al. (2010). The H‐Y scale was used to assess the disease stage, and part III of the Movement Disorder Society‐Sponsored Revision of the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (MDS‐UPDRS‐III) (Goetz et al., 2008) was used to measure the severity of motor symptoms. Global cognitive status was tested by administering the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) and the Mini‐Mental State Examination (MMSE). To assess whether participants had cerebellar signs and symptoms, we defined cerebellar signs (−/+), where + is defined as having at least one of the following symptoms: gait ataxia, limb ataxia, cerebellar dysarthria, or cerebellar oculomotor dysfunction; otherwise, participants were labelled as −. All patients underwent clinical observation for more than 2 years after data acquisition to ensure the accuracy of the diagnosis.

sec.title: MRI data acquisition, preprocessing, and FC matrix construction
sec.p: The study was performed using a 3.0 T MRI scanner (Magnetom Verio, Siemens, Erlangen, Germany) with a 32‐channel head coil. The rs‐fMRI data were acquired consisting of 210 functional volumes using a single‐short gradient‐echo echo‐planar imaging sequence parallel to the anterior commissure‐posterior commissure plane with the following parameters: repetition time (TR) = 2000 ms, echo time (TE) = 30 ms, flip angle = 90°, field of view (FOV) = 224 × 224 mm2, matrix size = 64 × 64, slice thickness = 3.5 mm, slice gap = 0.7 mm, voxel size = 3.5 × 3.5 × 3.5 mm, and slice number = 33. High‐resolution three‐dimensional T1‐weighted images were acquired in sagittal orientation employing a three‐dimensional sagittal magnetization‐prepared rapid acquisition gradient echo sequence with the following parameters: TR = 5000 ms, TE = 2960 ms, flip angle = 12°, FOV = 256 × 256 mm2, matrix size = 256 × 256, slice thickness = 1 mm, no slice gap, voxel size = 1.0 × 1.0 × 1.0 mm, and slice number = 176.

Data preprocessing was performed using Data Processing & Analysis of Brain Imaging (DPABI) software (http://rfmri.org/dpabi) and Statistical Parametric Mapping software (SPM12; http://www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/) under the MATLAB R2017b platform (MathWorks, Sherborn, MA, USA). First, the first 10 volumes of the functional images were removed to ensure stabilization of the initial signal and adaptation of participants to the environment. Slice‐timing correction steps were performed, and the mean slice was selected as the reference slice. Then, realignment for head movement compensation by using a six‐parameter rigid body spatial transformation. Subjects were examined with no more than 2.5 mm displacement and <2.5° rotation in any direction. Next, the individual T1 images were coregistered to the mean functional image generated during realignment. Normalization of 3D‐T1 structural MRI images to the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space was performed by nonlinear warping based on Diffeomorphic Anatomical Registration Through Exponentiated Lie Algebra (DARTEL). Then, rs‐fMRI images were spatially normalized to the MNI space using the same parameters derived from the normalization of structural images. After normalization, all images were resampled to 3 × 3 × 3 mm. Subsequently, linear detrending and bandpass filtering (0.01–0.08 Hz) were carried out to control low‐frequency drift and high‐frequency physiological noise. Finally, to reduce the effects of motion and nonneuronal blood oxygen level‐dependent (BOLD) fluctuations, 24‐head motion parameters (six head‐motion parameters, six head‐motion parameters one time point before, and the 12 corresponding squared items) as well as the cerebrospinal fluid and white matter signals were removed as nuisance covariates.

The functional connectome was constructed by using the GRETNA toolbox (https://www.nitrc.org/projects/gretna/) based on Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM12) with MATLAB R2017b. To define the nodes, a standardized automated anatomical labeling (AAL) atlas (Tzourio‐Mazoyer et al., 2002) was used to divide the whole brain into 116 regions (90 cortical and subcortical noncerebellar brain regions and 26 cerebellar regions). The average rs‐fMRI time series within each region was separately extracted, and Pearson's correlation coefficients between the rs‐fMRI time series of each brain region were calculated to determine FC. Thus, the FC matrix (adjacency matrix) was constructed. Considering the ambiguous interpretation of negative correlations, we restricted the analysis to positive correlations and set the negative correlation coefficients as zero. Correlation coefficients were then Fisher z‐transformed to improve normality. This method has been widely used in previous brain network studies (Lu et al., 2018; Suo et al., 2017).

sec.title: Analysis of graph attributes
sec.p: We used a graph theory to compute network measures based on a previous study (Rubinov & Sporns, 2010), which illustrated how to calculate and understand the network measures. The sparsity threshold method was used to determine whether there was a connection between two nodes. Instead of using a single sparsity threshold, we used a variety of sparsity thresholds for all correlation matrices to explore brain functional network topology. To analyze network parameters (including global and nodal network metrics), the correlation coefficient matrix was transformed into a series of binarized matrices (5%–50%; interval: 1%). We also constructed 500 random networks by rearranging the edge weights in the original networks. Moreover, normalized values were generated by dividing the raw values by the mean of the random graph.

Network analyses were performed at two levels: the “global level” and the “nodal level”.
The global‐level metrics reflected the overall network organization, and we calculated several parameters: gamma, lambda, the small‐world coefficient (sigma) (Liao et al., 2017), characteristic path length (Lp), Cp, global efficiency (Eglob), and Eloca.
The attributes of each node (specific brain regions) were indicated by nodal‐level values, including nodal efficiency (Ne), degree centrality (Dc), and betweenness centrality (Bc). For each network metric (global and nodal), the area under the curve (AUC) over the sparsity range was calculated to assist group comparisons. AUC values provide summed scalar information regarding the brain functional connectome topology, which is free from issues associated with the selection of a single threshold and has been widely used in previous brain network studies (Prajapati & Emerson, 2021; Suo et al., 2017; Zheng et al., 2020).

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: Statistical analyses of the demographic and clinical characteristics were performed using SPSS software (version 20.0, http://www.spss.com). Age, MMSE score, and MoCA score differences between the MSA‐P, IPD, and HC groups were analyzed using one‐way ANOVA with post hoc Bonferroni tests, whereas gender differences were assessed using chi‐square tests. Disease duration, LEDD, H‐Y stage, and MDS‐UPDRS‐III scores were compared between MSA‐P and IPD patients with two‐sample t tests. The threshold of significance was 0.05 (two‐tailed).

Functional connectome parameters were divided into two types: graph measures and raw connectivity matrices. These parameters were statistically analyzed using the GRETNA toolbox as follows:
One‐way ANOVA with age, gender, and education as covariates (ANCOVA) was used to assess global and nodal graph theory metrics between groups, followed by post hoc pairwise comparisons. For the nodal metrics, a false discovery rate (FDR) correction at an adjusted significance level of 0.05 was added for multiple comparisons.
Comparisons of raw connectivity matrices among groups were investigated using ANCOVA at a significance level of 0.05 to determine the statistical significance of differences in FC across the three groups; the ANCOVA was followed by post hoc two‐sample t tests. To address the problem of multiple comparisons, a network‐based statistics (NBS) correction method was added. Moreover, a nonparametric permutation test with 5000 repetitions was used.

sec.title: Correlation analysis
sec.p: After identifying substantial between‐group differences in graph metrics, we retrieved their AUC values. To explain whether significantly different variables were associated with clinical symptoms, we examined the correlations between these values and neuropsychological scores (including MMSE, MoCA, and MDS‐UPDRS‐III scores and H‐Y stage) in both patients and controls using Pearson's correlation analysis. The significance threshold was set at 0.05.

sec.title: Machine learning (feature selection and classification)
sec.p: Beyond testing for intergroup differences in the functional connectome, we were interested in assessing the usefulness of these connectome metrics in discriminating between MSA‐P and IPD patients using a supervised learning algorithm. The similarity in neural networks makes MSA‐P and IPD difficult to distinguish. To overcome this problem, each subject's extracted feature vector had 7083 elements (7083 = 3 [local metrics] × 116 [AAL areas] + 7 [global metrics] + 116 × 116/2 (connectivity matrices)).

To establish the model, we randomly divided all subjects into two datasets while maintaining the MSA‐P:IPD ratio; one dataset that included 103 subjects (61 MSA‐P, 42 IPD) as the training dataset and the other one that included 26 subjects (15 MSA‐p, 11 IPD) as the validation dataset. The training dataset served as a cohort for feature selection and model training, and the validation dataset was used to test the selected features and evaluate the predictive performance of the model.

Because of the large number of features and the relatively small sample size, an optimal subset of features was selected from the original feature set using a feature selection algorithm. Three feature selection methods were applied to the training dataset. First, min‐max normalization was performed on all 7083 features in the training dataset. Then, to eliminate irrelevant and redundant features, we used a two‐sample t test to determine the features with significant differences (p < 0.5) between MSA‐P and IPD. FDR correction was added for nodal graph metrics, and NBS correction was added for FC matrices. Thereafter, the random forest (RF) method with 10‐fold cross‐validation was used to build a subset of the most discriminative features from the high‐dimensional feature vector. Specifically, features were ranked in order of importance by the RF algorithm in each iteration, and the top 15 features with feature importance were selected. This information is saved in the form of indices/names of the selected features. The times each feature had been selected were counted and ranked, and the top 15 features that were selected more times were selected. Finally, Spearman's rank correlation coefficient was used to analyze the correlations between the remaining connectome features. When the absolute value of the correlation coefficient was ≥0.7 and the p value was <0.05, one of the lower feature importance values was excluded.

After the feature selection stage, supervised machine learning methods were used to construct the classifier. In this study, we performed a model fitting procedure using SVM, RF, and logistic regression (LR) on subjects in the training set, and the hyperparameters for the models were identified using a grid search strategy. The optimized parameters are listed in Table S1.

Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves of these three methods were plotted. The AUC, accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV) were calculated to evaluate the performance of each model in the training dataset and in the validation dataset. The statistical significance of differences between AUCs in the validation dataset was calculated by Delong's test. Figure 1 provides a flowchart of the machine learning process.

caption.p: Flowchart of the machine learning process. First, the rs‐fMRI scans were preprocessed, and then a total of 7083 features were extracted (nodal metrics, global metrics, and FC matrices). Second, three methods, including t test, random forest, and removing features with high autocorrelation, were used to select the characteristics with high predictive performance. Finally, multiple machine learning models (SVM, random forest, logistic regression) were built to predict patients with MSA‐P or IPD. FC, functional connectivity; IPD, idiopathic Parkinson's disease; MSA‐P, multiple system atrophy with predominant parkinsonism; rs‐fMRI, resting‐state functional magnetic resonance imaging; SVM, support vector machine

sec.title: Demographic and clinical characteristics
sec.p: The clinical and demographic data of the included subjects are summarized in Table 1. Three IPD and two MSA‐P patients were excluded because their disease duration was >3 years, three IPD and four MSA‐P patients were excluded because their H‐Y stage was >2.5, and five IPD and two MSA‐P patients were excluded because of excessive head movement. No HC was excluded. Ultimately, 217 participants were included. Significant between‐group differences were observed for MMSE scores, MoCA scores, H‐Y stage, and MDS‐UPDRS‐III scores. The MSA‐P and IPD patients had lower MMSE and MoCA scores than HCs (p < 0.001). The MSA‐P patients had lower MoCA scores than the IPD patients (p = 0.001). There was no significant difference in MMSE scores between the IPD and MSA‐P patients (p = 0.11). However, the MSA‐P group exhibited higher H‐Y stage and MDS‐UPDRS‐III scores than the IPD group, which is related to the severity of the disease. Patients with MSA‐P showed a higher proportion of positive cerebellar signs than those in the IPD group and HCs.

caption.p: Demographics and clinical characteristics of subjects

fn.p: Note: Numerical variables are presented as mean ± standard deviation.

Abbreviations: cerebellar signs (−/+), + is defined as at least one of the following symptoms: gait ataxia, limb ataxia, cerebellar dysarthria, or cerebellar oculomotor dysfunction; otherwise, patients were labelled as −; HC, healthy control; H‐Y stage, Hoehn and Yahr staging; LEDD, levodopa equivalent daily dose; MDS‐UPDRS‐III, Movement Disorder Society‐Sponsored Revision of the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale‐part III (severity of motor symptoms); MMSE, Mini‐Mental State Examination; MSA‐P, multiple system atrophy with predominant parkinsonism; MoCA, montreal cognitive assessment; NA, not available; PD, Parkinson's disease.

sec.title: Global graph metrics
sec.p: With gamma >1, lambda >1, and sigma >1 over the 5%–50% sparsity range, all three groups (HC, IPD, and MSA‐P) displayed small‐world properties. These facts explain why this range was used in this study.

There were differences in Cp and Eloca values among the three groups (F = 5.869, p = 0.003; F = 5.963, p = 0.003). Both the MSA‐P patients and the IPD patients had considerably lower Cp (post hoc p = 0.001/0.048) than the HCs, and the MSA‐P patients had significantly lower Eloca (post hoc p = 0.001) than the HCs (shown in Figure 2). Moreover, there were no significant differences in Eglob (F = 0.466, p = 0.628), Lp (F = 0.050, p = 0.951), or sigma (F = 0.450, p = 0.638).

caption.p: Violin diagrams show differences in brain network topological properties between MSA‐P patients, IPD patients, and HCs. *p < 0.05. Cp, clustering coefficient; Eloca, local efficiency; HC, healthy control; IPD, idiopathic Parkinson's disease; MSA‐P, multiple system atrophy with predominant parkinsonism

sec.title: Nodal graph metrics
sec.p: Table 2 shows the brain areas that showed significant between‐group changes in at least one nodal parameter (FDR‐corrected p < 0.05). In comparison to the HCs, the IPD patients showed decreased node centrality (with at least one nodal parameter decreasing) in the bilateral medial superior frontal gyri, bilateral superior temporal gyri, right temporal pole‐superior temporal gyrus, and right middle temporal gyrus, while the MSA‐P patients showed decreased node centralities in the left dorsolateral frontal gyrus, right Heschl gyrus, right temporal pole‐superior temporal gyrus, and bilateral medial superior frontal gyri. There was no significant difference between the MSA‐P and IPD patients. Moreover, there were no increased node centralities in the patient groups.

caption.p: Regions showing decreased nodal centralities in the MSA‐P/IPD groups compared with HC participants

tr.th: p values for post hoc tests

fn.p: Note: Date are mean ± standard deviation.

Abbreviations: HC, healthy control; HES, Heschl gyrus; IPD, idiopathic Parkinson's disease; MSA‐P, multiple system atrophy with predominant parkinsonism; MTL, middle temporal gyrus; SFGdor, dorsolateral frontal gyrus; SFGmed, medial superior frontal gyrus; STG, superior temporal gyrus; TPOsup, temporal pole: superior temporal gyrus.
p value reach statistically significant differences for comparisons among MSA‐P, IPD, and HC participants obtained by using ANCOVA with FDR‐correlation.
p value reach statistically significant differences in PD and HC comparison after FDR‐correlation.
p value reach statistically significant differences in MSA‐P and HC comparison after FDR‐correlation.

sec.title: Disease‐related alterations in FC
sec.p: By applying NBS to the raw connectivity matrices, we detected a considerably altered network among the three groups (ANCOVA results are shown in Figure 3a). Both the patients with IPD (Figure 3b) and those with MSA‐P (Figure 3c) exhibited widespread FC abnormalities compared with HCs, while there was heterogeneity between them (Figure 3d). Referring to the studies of Yeo et al. (2011) and Power et al. (2011), we present the FC results as regions in functional networks.

caption.p: Three brain networks that were significantly different between groups. These networks were calculated using NBS on the raw FC matrices in patients with MSA‐P, IPD, and HCs. The scale of circles represents the AAL brain areas. The lines in the circle represent the connections. (a) The grey lines denote connectivity significantly different after ANCOVA. (b) The red lines denote lower connectivity in MSA‐P compared with HCs. (c) The blue lines denote lower connectivity in IPD patients than in HCs. (d) The green lines denote lower connectivity in IPD patients than in MSA‐P patients, while the orange lines denote higher connectivity in MSA‐P patients than in IPD patients. AAL, automated anatomical labeling; FC, functional connectivity; HC, healthy control; IPD, idiopathic Parkinson's disease; MSA‐P, multiple system atrophy with predominant parkinsonism; NBS, network‐based statistics

sec.title: MSA‐P‐related alterations in FC
sec.p: Figure 3b shows that the network in MSA‐P patients (NBS‐corrected p < 0.001), including 119 connections and 71 regions, was statistically significant. These connections were mostly in the cerebellum, DMN, SMN, basal ganglia network (BGN), salience network, and frontoparietal networks. For all connections, FC was significantly reduced in the MSA‐P patients. All the connections were decreased in the MSA‐P patients compared with the HCs.

sec.title: IPD‐related alterations in FC
sec.p: Figure 3c shows the network in IPD patients (NBS‐corrected p < 0.001), which included 45 nodes and 86 connections linking the visual network, DMN, SMN, salience network, dorsal attention network, BGN, and temporal‐occipital regions. All the connections were decreased in the IPD patients compared with the HCs.

sec.title: MSA‐P and IPD differences in FC
sec.p: One connected component comprising 115 connections and 64 regions was significant between MSA‐P and IPD (NBS‐corrected p < 0.001; Figure 3d). Compared to the MSA‐P patients, the IPD patients had impaired FC in the DMN and BGN. The MSA‐P patients had lower intercerebellar and cerebellar‐DMN FC than IPD patients.

sec.title: Correlation analysis
sec.p: DC (r = −0.202, p = 0.044) and Ne (r = −0.312, p = 0.002) in the right superior temporal gyrus were negatively correlated with MDS‐UPDRS‐III scores in the IPD group.

sec.title: Feature selection
sec.p: Each participant's connectome had 7083 characteristics. The two‐sample t‐test step decreased 7083 features to 147 features, which included two global graph theory attributes: Cp and Eloca; 15 node attributes: eight DC, six Ne, and one BC; and 115 connections. Then, the top 15 features were selected by the RF algorithm with 10‐fold cross‐validation. Finally, the procedure to exclude variables with an absolute correlation greater than 0.7 removed 0 features, leaving a total of 15 features (14 connections and 1 nodal metric) chosen for binary classification (shown in Figure 4 and Table 3).

caption.p: The spatial distribution of the 15 most discriminative features (14 connections and 1 nodal metric) after feature selection. The color of the node represents the brain network to which this node belongs: yellow, the default‐mode network (DMN); green, dorsal attention network; light blue, visual network (VA); dark blue, salience network; pink, basal ganglia network (BGN); dark purple, cerebellum network (CEN). The enlarged yellow nodes indicate the left middle temporal gyrus, for which node efficiency showed discriminating value
Top 15 connectome features with maximum discriminative ability selected by RF for differentiating MSA‐P from IPD patients

fn.p: Abbreviations: AAL, automated anatomical labeling; BGN, basal ganglia network; CEN, cerebellum network; DMN, default‐mode network; FC, functional connectivity; IPD, idiopathic Parkinson's disease; MSA‐P, multiple system atrophy with predominant parkinsonism; Ne, nodal efficiency; RF, random forest.

sec.title: Classification
sec.p: Table 4 shows the classification accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity. Figure 5 depicts the classifier's ROC curve. Table 4 and Figure 5 show that RF outperformed LR and SVM in terms of overall accuracy and AUC in the training dataset (p = 0.01, Delong's test), and LR had a higher AUC than SVM (p = 0.03). However, the focus needs to be on the classification in the validation set. In the validation dataset, there was no significant difference in AUC between the models (RF vs. LR: p = 0.26; SVM vs. LR: p = 0.18; RF vs. SVM: p = 0.14; Delong's test). The LR model performed better in terms of accuracy and specificity in the validation dataset. In summary, LR was the optimal model in our opinion for this situation.

caption.p: Performance of classification using various models

fn.p: Abbreviations: AUC, area under the receiver operating characteristic curve; LR, logistic regression; NPV, negative predictive value; PPV, positive predictive value; RF, random forest; SVM, support vector machine.

caption.p: ROC curves of each model index on the training (left) and validation datasets (right). The AUC, accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, PPV, and NPV were calculated and are shown in Table 4. AUC, area under the curve; NPV, negative predictive value; PPV, positive predictive value; ROC, receiver operating characteristic

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The aim of the present study was to determine whether MSA‐P patients had specific functional connectome disruptions compared with IPD patients and HCs using MRI.

Overall, our major findings demonstrated that (1) early‐stage IPD and MSA‐P patients displayed similar network topological traits, such as decreased local specialization in the whole brain and reduced node centrality in the frontotemporal cortex. (2) Within the cerebellum‐basal ganglia‐cortical network, MSA‐P and IPD patients exhibited significantly distinct forms of “disconnection” (i.e., a decrease in FC). The cerebellum‐cortical circuit was severely “disconnected” in the MSA‐P patients, and the basal ganglia‐cortical circuit was significantly “disconnected” in the IPD patients. This specific damage pattern has not been comprehensively reported in earlier studies (Baggio et al., 2019; Sako et al., 2019). More crucially, we discovered evidence that rs‐fMRI functional connectome measures have strong discriminative ability in early IPD and MSA‐P, implying that the functional connectome could be employed as imaging indicators for diagnosis.

sec.title: Similarities of topological properties in IPD and MSA‐P
sec.p: Through a graph theory approach, the patients with IPD and MSA‐P showed similar global (lower Cp and Eloca) and nodal (lower node centralities in the DMN and temporal areas) abnormalities compared to the HCs, which supported the similarity of their clinical symptoms. Furthermore, the DC and Ne in the right superior temporal gyrus were negatively correlated with MDS‐UPDRS‐III scores in the IPD group. In accordance with our results, published studies (De Micco et al., 2021; Luo et al., 2015) reported decreased local specialization (marked by decreases in Cp and Eloca) with global integration remaining unchanged in the brain functional network of early‐stage PD patients. Other studies (Chung et al., 2020; Huang et al., 2019; Suo et al., 2017) reported a decreased global efficiency (Huang et al., 2019) and an increased characteristic path length (Suo et al., 2017) in patients with advanced IPD. According to a comprehensive examination of our and others' research, the brain networks in patients with IPD may ultimately fail to maintain global integration as the disease develops. Our and other research suggests that as IPD advances, brain networks may lose global integration. Similar patterns of injury have been observed in several neurodegenerative illnesses, including Alzheimer's disease (Behfar et al., 2020), IPD (Chung et al., 2020; De Micco et al., 2021), and dementia with Lewy bodies (Lu et al., 2018).

Moreover, our findings further confirmed previous findings that the node centrality values of the medial superior frontal gyrus and the middle and superior temporal gyri are diminished in both diseases. De Micco et al. (2021) and Suo et al. (2017) found that IPD patients showed early anomalies in the temporal cortex and decreasing node centralities in the sensorimotor cortex as the disease progressed. Zheng et al. (2020) revealed aberrant nodal metrics in MSA patients in several prefrontal areas, cerebellar hemispheres and vermis areas. However, Sako et al. (2019) found no significant differences in graph theory metrics between groups in a limited sample (11 MSA, 23 IPD, and 11 HCs). Finally, because graph theory analyses of rs‐fMRI studies of MSA are rare, sample sizes have been inadequate, and previous studies have not used the dual syndrome hypothesis to analyse subtypes of MSA, our results are difficult to compare with earlier investigations.

sec.title: Widespread disrupted functional connections in IPD and MSA‐P
sec.p: Other than these altered topological properties, we compared whole‐brain FC between the MSA‐P, IPD, and HC groups and found extensive “disconnection” in both the MSA‐P and IPD groups. Since pathological processes such as Lewy body accumulation, myelin degradation, and oligodendrogliopathy may affect synaptic activity rather than kill neurons, monitoring synaptic activity in the early stages of disease is critical. rs‐fMRI signals correlate with synaptic activity (Logothetis & Wandell, 2004). The IPD patients exhibited lower FC in the BGN and various cortical regions than the HCs, which was consistent with neuropathologic findings showing Lewy body pathological structure patterns across Braak stages 3 to 5 (Braak et al., 2003). The patients with MSA‐P also had similar outcomes in the cortical regions. In addition, MSA‐P patients showed additional FC reductions in the cerebellum‐cortical regions and intercerebellar connections, which are known to be involved in MSA pathology (Valdinocci et al., 2018).

sec.title: Different disconnection patterns within the cerebellum‐basal ganglia‐cerebral cortex network
sec.p: Notably, FC strength in the basal ganglia‐thalamo‐cortical (BTC) circuit in the MSA‐P group was stronger than that in the IPD group but weaker than that in the HC group, whereas FC strength in the cortico‐thalamo‐cerebellar (CTC) circuit in the MSA‐P group was weaker than that in the IPD and HC groups. Our findings are consistent with traditional neuropathology beliefs and previous fMRI findings (Ji et al., 2018; Muller‐Oehring et al., 2015) that aberrant activity in the complex BTC circuit is crucial to IPD and that “disconnection” is associated with the onset of motor and nonmotor symptoms. According to Szewczyk‐Krolikowski et al. (2014), the average FC strength within the BGN has the ability to distinguish IPD patients from HCs. The CTC circuit disruption we discovered was mostly in MSA‐related pathology brain areas, that is, the vermis and cerebellar hemispheres. In addition, some MSA‐P patients in this study showed signs of cerebellar injury symptoms, while no IPD patient showed symptoms of cerebellar injury, which supported our finding that the CTC circuit was “disconnected” in MSA‐P patients. A number of previous studies (Baggio et al., 2019; Ren et al., 2018; N. Wang et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2019; Yao et al., 2017) have observed intracerebellar and CTC circuit “disconnection” in MSA (Baggio et al., 2019; N. Wang et al., 2019) or MSA‐P (Yang et al., 2019; Yao et al., 2017) patients when compared to HCs, which could be the cause of a variety of clinical symptoms. In our earlier study (N. Wang et al., 2019), CTC disconnections in MSA patients were more extensive than those in IPD patients, and motor/cognitive scores were associated with cerebellar‐DMN FC strength. In contrast to others, Yao et al. (2017) discovered that IPD patients have weaker cerebellar‐DMN (posterior cingulate cortex and inferior parietal lobe) FC strength than MSA‐P patients or HCs. The contradictory results may be caused by multiple factors, such as medication status, inadequate sample size, and sample heterogeneity.

As major subcortical systems, the basal ganglia and cerebellum were assumed to be independent and communicating only at the level of the cerebral cortex (through BTC and CTC circuits). In the last decade, the results of neuroanatomical studies have suggested that the cerebellum and basal ganglia are intensively interconnected at the subcortical level (Bostan et al., 2010; Caligiore et al., 2017; C. H. Chen et al., 2014) and communicate in real time to provide appropriate inputs to the cerebral cortices. Consequently, a new functional perspective (Bostan et al., 2018; Bostan & Strick, 2018) has received close attention from neuroscientists that states that the cerebral cortex, the basal ganglia, and the cerebellum are not independent information processing systems but form integrated networks. This network, the cerebellum‐basal ganglia‐cortical network, influences not only movement but also cognitive and emotional functions.

According to our findings, both MSA‐P and IPD are implicated in abnormal activity of the cerebellum‐basal ganglia‐cortical network, but they affect different key nodes. Disconnection in the BTC circuit was linked to IPD, while disconnection in the CTC circuit was linked to MSA‐P. This explains the similar clinical performances under different pathological alterations as well as poorer outcomes in MSA patients with deep brain stimulation treatment.

Furthermore, the functional connectome has the capacity to discriminate between IPD and MSA‐P patients at the single‐patient level. In contrast with traditional statistical methods that emphasize their interpretability, the machine learning approach emphasizes large‐scale applications and predictive accuracy. To the best of our knowledge, most previous studies based on resting‐state FC/connectome/graph theory have investigated MSA or IPD alone. Most of these studies lacked independent validation sets, did not compare MSA and IPD, or did not employ the dual syndrome theory to identify MSA subtypes. Baggio et al. applied a machine learning method based on measures of cerebellar FC and achieved an overall classification accuracy of 77.17% (Baggio et al., 2019). Our study considered altered FC in both the basal BTC and CTC circuits, applied independent training and validation sets, and achieved higher classification accuracy (92.31% in the validation set).

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: Our study investigated brain connectome alterations in MSA‐P and IPD using a variety of methodologies (graph theory, whole‐brain FC, and machine learning). Furthermore, this approach yielded good accuracy for MSA‐P and IPD classification.

Several limitations exist in the present study. First, the limited sample size and the imbalanced neuropsychological test scores between MSA‐p and IPD may affect the results, especially when evaluating the discriminating ability of the models. Second, the patients were diagnosed with probable MSA‐P or IPD by senior neurological kinesiologists based on strict clinical diagnostic criteria and 2 years of follow‐up observations. However, because postmortem pathological examinations were lacking, misdiagnosis cannot be completely excluded. Third, the cumulative effects of anti‐parkinsonian drugs may have also affected brain function. Therefore, further studies are needed to explore potential differences between drug‐naive and treated IPD/MSA‐P patients to assess the effect of drugs on the topological properties of brain networks. Longitudinal studies are needed to assess the predictive value of these functional modifications regarding prognosis and efficacy. In addition, the extracted FC parameters are static FC parameters that represent the average state of FC of the brain within a time period. However, the changes in the FC on the temporal scale are termed dynamic FC, which offers more information; thus, future research should focus on the changes in the dynamic FC in PD and MSA‐P.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: We investigated brain functional connectome abnormalities in patients with IPD and MSA‐P using graph theory and FC techniques based on rs‐fMRI. Our findings demonstrated that MSA‐P and IPD patients exhibit dysfunction in a wide range of brain areas, with “disconnection” within the cortico‐basal ganglia‐cerebellar network serving as the cornerstone of a differential diagnosis. IPD patients have decreased FC in the basal ganglia‐cortical circuit, whereas early‐stage MSA‐P patients have reduced FC in the cerebellum‐cortical circuit. Our results not only add new evidence for the underlying neurobiological differences between MSA‐P and IPD but also demonstrate the early differential diagnostic potential of the functional connectome.

sec.title: AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS
sec.p: Guoguang Fan: conceptualization and supervision of the study. Boyu Chen: validation, investigation, writing – original draft preparation. Anlan Sun, Jiachuan He: methodology, visualization. Shanshan Wang reviewed and edited the manuscript. Hongmei Yu, Wenzhuo Cui: neuropsychological assessment. Yu Liu: data acquisition and curation.
